rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;7e985843.1503">   <title>BARS: Fully-funded PhD deadline reminder </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;7e985843.1503</link>   <description> The AHRC-funded \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdCurious Travellers\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd project is pleased to advertise a fully-funded PhD, to start 1st October 2015, exploring any aspect of C18th and Romantic-period tours to Wales and Scotland. The post will be based in the University of Wales Centre for Advanced Welsh and Celtic Studies (CAWCS) in Aberystwyth, and will run for three years. We invite applicants to offer ideas from a broad spectrum of possible research topics within the main subject of 'The Welsh and Scottish Tour 1760-1820'. Suggestions might include (but are not restricted to):<br>Perceptions of Wales and the Welsh/ Scotland and the Scots in written [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:36:17+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;7e985843.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;25792fe2.1503">   <title>BARS: CFP Eighteenth-Century Crossovers: Gender, Genre, Geography </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;25792fe2.1503</link>   <description> Our proposed collection aims to explore the meanings of crossover in the eighteenth century. The concept of crossover grew out of the uneasy reconcilement between the era\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds belief in the absoluteness of taxonomical categories and its paradoxical insistence on the potential malleability and manipulability of the same. Sweeping changes in the cultural scene challenged the seeming discreteness between conceptual kinds, and unleashed the possibility of transcending boundaries of all sorts. For instance, the spurt of popular interest in humanoid automata (Jaquet-Droz\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds The Writer and Kemplen\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds The Turk), animalistic humans (the natural man, the freak, or wild children) and anthropomorphic animals [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:13:13+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;25792fe2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;923828c2.1503">   <title>BARS: CFP Maroons, Indigenous Peoples, and Indigeneity </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;923828c2.1503</link>   <description> CALL FOR PAPERS<br><br>Maroons, Indigenous Peoples, and Indigeneity June 19-23, 2015 Charles Town, Portland, Jamaica<br><br>The Seventh Charles Town International Maroon Conference invites papers that explore the relationships between place and tradition in Indigenous and Maroon communities around the globe.<br><br>Held in the Maroon community of Charles Town surrounded by Jamaica's Blue and John Crow Mountains, this interdisciplinary conference will explore issues, values, and practices of Maroons and indigenous peoples as well as ideas about marronage and indigeneity to consider the ways they have endured, transformed, and resonated in the Caribbean, Canada, Australia, South America, Europe, the United States, and [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:13:05+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;923828c2.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;fde947b.1503">   <title>BARS: Funded PhD in Romanticism at Northumbria University </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;fde947b.1503</link>   <description> Funded PhD in Romanticism at Northumbria University<br><br>Northumbria University is offering a funded PhD (covering tuition fees and an annual stipend at RCUK rates: for 2015/16 this is \ufffd\ufffd14,057 p.a.). The PhD allows you to develop an original project in the expanding and dynamic field of Romantic-period literature and work as part of a large research community in Newcastle upon Tyne. We would particularly welcome applications which consider relations between Romanticism and audience and/or the marketplace for print, regional Romanticism, and Romantic experiments in genre.<br>Further details are available here:<br>http://www.findaphd.com/search/ProjectDetails.aspx?PJID=61847&amp;LID=2307<br>The closing date is 31 March 2015 [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:12:56+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;fde947b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;21404e1f.1503">   <title>BARS: CFP Reminder: Waterloo conference Brussels 18-19 June 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;21404e1f.1503</link>   <description> Dear all,<br><br>Just a quick reminder that we are still accepting proposals (until 20 March) for papers for our conference on the transnational reception of Waterloo. Apart from the great line-up of keynote speakers, also bear in mind that the conference takes place on the days of the bicentenary and less than 20km from the battlefield! [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:12:26+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;21404e1f.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;a3651cc3.1503">   <title>BARS: Romantic Materialities - a Romantic Circles PRAXIS Volume </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;a3651cc3.1503</link>   <description> Romantic Materialities, a Romantic Circles PRAXIS Volume (February 2015)<br>Romantic Circles has announced the release of Romantic Materialities, a volume in its PRAXIS series edited by Sarah Guyer and Celeste Langan, which contains:<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRomantic Materialities, or \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThis is not a Thing'\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Sara Guyer, University of Wisconsin, Madison and Celeste Langan, University of California, Berkeley<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMaterial Excursions\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Brian McGrath, Clemson University<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWhat Wordsworth Touched\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Sonia Hofkosh, Tufts University<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdKilling What Is Already Dead: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdOriginal Materialism,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Translation and Romanticism after de Man\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Tom Toremans, KU Leuven<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLiterary Immanence\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Mario Ortiz-Robles, University of [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:12:33+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;a3651cc3.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;8e020734.1503">   <title>BARS: 2015 Jane Austen Summer Program, Emma at 200! </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;8e020734.1503</link>   <description> Dear colleagues,<br><br>On behalf of the Jane Austen Summer Program, I am writing to invite you to our upcoming conference at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.<br><br>See below for details.<br><br>Best,<br><br>Suzanna Geiser<br>Ph.D. Student and Teaching Fellow<br>Department of English and Comparative Literature<br>University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill<br><br>Announcing the 2015 Jane Austen Summer Program, Emma at 200!<br>June 18-21, 2015 at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:12:05+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;8e020734.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;b4fd764a.1503">   <title>BARS: CFP Extended Deadline: Romanticism and the South-West </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;b4fd764a.1503</link>   <description> Romanticism and the South-West<br>** Extended Deadline**<br><br>The English department at the University of Bristol invites submissions for a 1-day conference to be held on the 29th of June, 2015, on the subject of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRomanticism and the South-West\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.<br>The conference aims to explore the importance of the South-West for Romantic writers, with a particular emphasis on the following topics: 1) ecologically aware writing and protoenvironmental thought; 2) the role of the South-West in an era of scientific development and discovery; 3) the South-West as a centre for reform movements and radical politics, as well as a region connected to slavery [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:11:51+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;b4fd764a.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;b308a110.1503">   <title>BARS: CFP Edinburgh Companion to Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Print Media in Britain, 1690-1820</title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;b308a110.1503</link>   <description> CFP for Edinburgh Companion to Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Print Media in Britain, 1690-1820, ed. Jennie Batchelor (Kent) and Manushag Powell (Purdue)<br><br>The editors of this volume, the first in an exciting new five-volume research companion series for Edinburgh University Press, welcome abstracts on women and print media (primarily periodicals and magazines) in the long eighteenth century. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T07:11:05+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;b308a110.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;aa4add71.1503">   <title>BARS: CFP War and Representation Network Conference Anniversary Culture II </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;aa4add71.1503</link>   <description> War and Representation Network Conference Anniversary Culture II:<br>1815 and 1915: From Waterloo to Gallipoli Saturday 21 November 2015, University of Leicester<br>Keynote Speakers:<br>Professor Simon Bainbridge, University of Lancaster Professor Jane Chapman, University of Lincoln<br><br>Proposals are invited for the second in a series of conferences to mark the centenary years of the First World War and their intersections with other anniversaries. Focusing on the memorialization of 1815 and 1915 in poetry, the novel, non-fiction and the visual arts, this conference will offer the chance to reconsider the representation of the key events of those years in both the [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:23:19+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;aa4add71.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;80bed85f.1503">   <title>BARS: Latest Issue - Keats-Shelley Journal </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;80bed85f.1503</link>   <description> Keats-Shelley Journal 63 (2014)<br>In Articles on March 4, 2015 at 6:31 pm<br>The Keats-Shelley Journal has announced the release of volume 63 (2014), which contains:<br><br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPeacock\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Lost Epilogue to Skeffington\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds *Lose No Time*\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Nicholas A. Joukovsky<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdA Note from Godwin to Ollier in the Year of Reform\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Rebecca Nesvet<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRediscovered Shelley and Keats Manuscripts in Krakow\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Stephanie Dumke<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdWilliam Hilton\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Lost Drawing of Keats\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Scott McEathron<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Poetry of Wandering: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdMont Blanc\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in *History of a Six Weeks\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Tour*\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Michael Erkelenz<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdShelley, Urbanization, and Artificial Forms of Society\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd by Stephen Tedeschi<br>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPassive and Dynamic [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:15:04+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;80bed85f.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;9a1c07fc.1503">   <title>BARS: Napoleon\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Last Stand: 100 Days in 100 Objects</title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;9a1c07fc.1503</link>   <description> Napoleon\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Last Stand: 100 Days in 100 Objects<br><br>An online exhibition, curated by the University of Warwick, will provide a new angle on the Battle of Waterloo, whose bicentennial anniversary is commemorated this year.<br><br>Everybody knows about Waterloo, of course, but fewer people know that Napoleon had already been defeated and exiled one year earlier and that in a dramatic turn of events in February 1815, he escaped from Elba, raised an army, and marched on Paris. Having toppled the newly restored monarchy, he reinstated the Empire \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and only then faced the Allies at Waterloo in June. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:15:54+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;9a1c07fc.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;dccb81e.1503">   <title>BARS: AHRC Fully-Funded Doctoral Studentship in Scottish Romanticism </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;dccb81e.1503</link>   <description> AHRC Fully-Funded Doctoral Studentship: Scottish Romanticism and the Short Story<br><br>The School of Arts and Humanities is pleased to invite applications for this three-year, fully-funded AHRC PhD Studentship (fees and subsistence at current AHRC UK/EU rates).<br><br>The studentship arises from a major three-year AHRC-funded project at the University of Stirling, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdJames Hogg: Contributions to International Periodicals\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. Led by Dr Suzanne Gilbert and Dr Adrian Hunter, the project investigates Hogg's many contributions to magazines and newspapers around the English-speaking world, from Ireland to North America, Australia, and New Zealand. A scholarly edition of these diverse writings is being prepared by Dr [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:15:39+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;dccb81e.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;5893e613.1503">   <title>BARS: Second Edition Wordsworth's Bardic Vocation, 1787-1842 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;5893e613.1503</link>   <description> Excuse a shameless plug, but you may like to know that this hitherto rare item, Wordsworth's Bardic Vocation, 1787-1842, first published at \ufffd\ufffd90, is now available in a second edition.<br><br>The revised and enlarged (420 pp) paperback is \ufffd\ufffd17.96 direct from the printer (see link below), \ufffd\ufffd11.95 in PDF or KIndle. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:15:28+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;5893e613.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;43c668cc.1503">   <title>BARS: Spring Issue of The BARS Review </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;43c668cc.1503</link>   <description> Dear members,<br><br>The Spring Issue of The BARS Review is now available online at the following address: http://www.bars.ac.uk/review/index.php/barsreview<br><br>You can access/download individual reviews or the whole number in either PDF or Html formats.<br><br>We hope you enjoy reading this bumper issue, introducing our new special feature on European Romanticism.<br><br>with all best wishes,<br>the editorial team   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:15:47+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;43c668cc.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;a6f14187.1503">   <title>BARS: Latest Issue - European Romantic Review </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;a6f14187.1503</link>   <description> European Romantic Review 26.2 (April 2015) now available<br>In Articles on February 25, 2015 at 9:58 pm<br>The new issue of European Romantic Review, 26.2, is out. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:14:11+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;16cdca6c.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;148e8e8e.1503">   <title>BARS: CFP Rethinking Cultural Memory (1700-1850) </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;148e8e8e.1503</link>   <description> Conference<br>Rethinking Cultural Memory (1700-1850)<br><br>Call for Papers<br><br>The Nordic Association for Romantic Studies (NARS) is pleased to announce the Call for Papers for the international conference \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRethinking Cultural Memory 1700-1850\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. The conference will take place at Copenhagen University, Denmark, Friday 4 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Saturday 5 December 2015. The period 1700-1850 saw the birth of the modern nation state and of the concept of national/regional identities based on ethnicity, language, cultural memory, and literary heritage. The romantic and post-romantic era in Europe was a watershed when a neglected vernacular heritage was processed from one medium to another. Poetry, novels, and painting [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T05:14:33+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;148e8e8e.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;99974e77.1503">   <title>BARS: Reminder: Coleridge and Contemplation, Kyoto 27-29 March, 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;99974e77.1503</link>   <description> Reminder: Coleridge and Contemplation, Kyoto 27-29 March, 2015<br><br>http://kyotocontemplation.org/plenary-speakers/<br><br>Three days: thirty-four lectures and shorter talks:<br><br>Jim Mays (University College Dublin): Contemplation in Coleridge\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Poetry<br>Douglas Hedley (Cambridge University): Coleridge and Contemplation<br>David E. Cooper (Durham University): Meditation on the Move: walking, nature, mystery<br>Andy Hamilton (Durham University): Coleridge, Mill, and Conservatism<br>Setsuko Wake-Naota (Kobe College): Contemplating Genius: Coleridge on Shakespeare<br>David Vallins (Hiroshima University): Contemplation and Criticism: Coleridge, Derrida, and the sublime<br>Kaz Oishi (Tokyo University): Coleridge\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Contemplative Social Vision<br>James Kirwan (Kansai University): Coleridge on Beauty<br>Joseph S. T., edited by Harriet Kramer Linkin:<br><br>http://www.rc.umd.edu/editions/tighe_verses<br><br>The volume represents a manuscript collection of 121 original lyric poems with 72 original illustrations that Mary Tighe prepared in 1805 as she was contemplating publishing a volume of poetry that would feature her epic romance "Psyche; or, the Legend of Love" accompanied by a selection of her lyrics. Instead she opted to print 50 copies of Psyche; or, The Legend of Love (London, 1805) without any additions from Verses in a small private [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-20T04:28:15+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;d818abd9.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;86995f6b.1502">   <title>BARS: New Issue: La questione Romantica </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;86995f6b.1502</link>   <description> New Issue: La questione Romantica, 3.2 (2014)<br>New Perspectives on William Wordsworth<br>Ed. By reading beyond the texts conventionally associated with Romanticism, and by recasting the critical tendencies\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfrom thing theory to object oriented ontology\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthrough the poets, genres, and critics of Romanticism, these essays position Romanticism [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-13T01:45:57+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator> For Papers: The Humanities in a Utilitarian Age<br>A Special Issue of Humanities<br>Guest Editor, Paul Keen<br><br>Marjorie Perloff\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds comment that \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdone of our most common genres today is the epitaph for the humanities\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is borne out by the barrage of disturbing evidence that has become a daily part of our working experience as teachers and researchers within universities. These problems, however, also constitute an important opportunity: a chance to re-imagine our answers to questions about the nature and role of the humanities, and why they matter. Responding to this challenge successfully, however, requires a better understanding of the [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-13T01:35:48+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Neil Ramsey</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;29a83d19.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;7fbad3c2.1502">   <title>BARS: CFP Recording Nature in the Early Atlantic World, 1750-1830 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BARS;7fbad3c2.1502</link>   <description> CALL FOR PAPERS<br>Recording Nature in the Early Atlantic World, 1750-1830<br>October 8-10, 2015<br>Tampa Bay, Florida<br>A conference sponsored by the Charles Brockden Brown Society<br>(www.brockdenbrownsociety.ucf.edu)<br><br>250-word proposal deadline: March 30, 2015<br>Please send proposal in .docx or .doc format to Elizabeth Hewitt (hewitt.33@osu.edu].<br>If you have any questions, please contact: Duncan Faherty (Duncan.Faherty@qc.cuny.edu)<br><br>The Charles Brockden Brown Society invites proposals that take up the broad theme of nature in the 18th and early 19th centuries.
